text: the recent demonstrations to the Olympic
torch relay have touched a sensitive
nerve for people in China and opened a
floodgate of national pride I
interviewed several local Chinese to get
their opinions jellison way no I fear
that I'm furious over it the spirit of
the Olympics consists of friendship and
peace the protesters have only damaged
their own image with this kind of
behavior magellan suppose it also
happens if this in myself well I think
the protesters themselves are kind of
shameful that they are just destroying
this spirit of the the only games vase
is really important for Chinese people a
lot of Chinese express their feelings
indirectly because they were afraid of
losing face with the Olympics coming up
Chinese feel they've lost a tremendous
amount of face due to the Tibetan
independence demonstrations of the
demonstrations in Paris several Chinese
newspapers focus on a disabled Chinese
torchbearer who was attacked by a
demonstrator labeling the event inhumane
are actually getting news about the
protest it's not being censored in the
state media although it is certainly
being shaped in the state media all the
protesters are being described as
Tibetan separatists they're continuing
to pursue the theme that he's protest as
trouble it's rooted in people who want
to divide China and that's such a
passionate and emotional issue here in
China for ordinary people even people
who might on other issues be critical
the government almost uniformly believe
in territorial integrity of what they
believe is China and they see Tibet
ordinary people here without question
believe Tibet is part of China
history suggests nationalism in China
can take on a life of its own in 2005
Chinese demonstrators voiced their
dissatisfaction over Japanese Prime
Minister Koizumi's visit to the Yasukuni
Shrine or war criminals guilty of
atrocities against the Chinese in world
war two are honored
nationalist sentiment in China got so
out of hand that Chinese riot police
clashed with demonstrators trying to
overrun the Japanese Consulate in
Shanghai
I rate Chinese tore down signs of
Japanese businesses in a bid to restore
order the chinese state media sent out
text messages stating all marches and
public gatherings expressing patriotic
sentiment needed to be orderly law
abiding and required permits above all
things the battle even spilled over onto
the internet the Chinese government shut
down several websites started by
ordinary Chinese citizens one of which
posted an online petition boycotting
business contracts between the Chinese
government and Japanese companies the
Patriots Alliance website as it was
called received 67,000 online signatures
from Chinese netizens within just 24
hours thus far anger over Tibetan
protests has stayed on the internet but
there are other signs that Chinese pride
is on the line right now
to Chinese Olympic gold medalists were
signing autographs for free only they
weren't really free in order to get an
autograph you had to buy a mini olympic
torch collectible purchasable next door
for 420 dollars Beijingers were buying
the torches to show their support for
the beleaguered torched or by the end of
the day the store had sold out in
Beijing this is jimmy wang for the new
york times
